I went to high school in the Oklahoma Panhandle & this year there'll be a big reunion of past students. I remember my close friends there but lately I've been getting letters from other students & can't remember any of them! Perhaps if I saw them.
Your autobiography is going well, I hope. And not too many distractions.
Good, good wishes to you Jack.
Sanora

THE TIGERS ARE GONE WITH THE WIND

July 10 1971
Dear Jack,
I want to get these papers back to you safe & sound, and will write you in a few days.
Thanks for sending them. I really enjoyed catching up a bit on your work and life - well, they aren't separate, but you understand what I mean. "Home to Mothers" all for more!
I'm glad for the tributes - you deserve them all and more. Perhaps the help you're given so many writers is an integral part of your work; it was, is, creative help. Of course, a writer who works hard, as you have, should have more recognition for his writing, but who knows how such things are determined? [I suspect you may know.] In any case, I know from experience how you feel. To me, of course you've been a famous writer for many years and by the reissue of "The

Disinherited" and the long unforgotten life it has, you've achieved something better than fame. I have the book among my 30's books in plain sight. My sister (Dorothy) and I are going to reread it. We aren't the only ones. You'll get a whole new readership with the paperback.
Well, a letter soon.* I thank you for printing "Dry Summer" in the April, and I thank you for your review and letter and the enclosed.
Good wishes with the autobiography. It will be a good book I'm looking forward to reading.
Sanora
(Babb)

That sounds as if I'm about to inundate you with a correspondence - No - writers must write their work> But this is a hasty note & you'd think I have only one sheet of paper to my name.

Dear Jack, I've thought of you often I wanted to write of all these printed goodies from you, off & on. Now here's your Christmas note & I'm glad to hear. Also I'm late because I've just got my Jimmie home from hospital, again - in & out this year, but we're ever hopeful, & he's better. He managed to make "Funny Lady" (B. Streisand) in spring & summer, & in fall was honored by the S.F. Film Festival. Lots of honors coming in & all deserved. But it's sad to see him ill.
I report no work worth mentioning the whole year, but a hard year. Did write you the Country Book Club of England selected "Owl"? So had an extra 6,000 edition & a third hardcover & one paperback. I've started a new book, and hope to do more this yr.
No, I did not see the Nation review of "Writers in Revolt" & sorry I missed it. But glad it was good.
All your chapters being published

should get you a publisher at once. I hope you have a good year of work on that book - it's going to be good. I'm looking forward. My unknown writes me, so for you - "Keep on keeping on.
The only print I have coming for the next year so far is a poem in Southwest Review. By the way, SW would like your chapters, I'm sure. Have you tired there? Ed. Margaret Hartley is overworked & slow to reply but sincere & a good editor. A fine year to you!
Lanora??

Dec 17 1975
Dear Jack,
I'm glad for your note and the news of "Writers in Revolt", but I wish for your sake it would sell more. Maybe it isn't the "right" kind of nostalgia so fashionable now. I've been wondering how your Autobiography is coming along. I don't know how you sort but all your experiences for one volume, won't there be more? I feel as if I'll die with all my books unwritten. By the time the varied experiences unknown for recreating, years go by. I worked almost none this year & completed nothing. Two stories begun.
Jimmie has been terribly ill all year (in bed) & I got him out of hospital in March so I could take better care of him at home. He's a little better but very ill & weak. He's been courageous & uncomplaining, but is about to give up. He can't bear the thoh of not working again, but he did make "Funny Lady" & its up for nomination, and he has rec'd many honors.
There's a big newstand here that sells a lot of literary magazines. December has a high reputation. I'll watch for it to read your chapter. I enjoy reading Conroy.
Very sorry to hear about Ben Hagglund. The last I heard from him he was feeling happy again. I'll write him

Babb, Sanora
Hollywood, CA
May the Peace and Joy of the Holiday Season Be Yours Throughout the Coming Year
I hope you have a find writing year, Jack. I'll be looking forward to the book.
Have I told you a Berkely publisher (small, but has done quite well with the 15 or so books) wants to publish my migratory farm worker novels (1938)? I'm trying to find time to read it thru. It was a first draft - so - but I can't rewrite it now. If it isn't too bad I'll agree. Merry Christmas!
Fondly,
Sanora

Best Wishes in this Holiday Season
Dear Jack,
Just reread "The Morphodite" - still smiling. I hope you've been able to give more time to your book. I want to go in the bookstores, ask for it & buy several copies for myself and friends. And enjoy reading about your life. You can't get it all in one volume, can you?
That was a sincerely appreciative review of the anthology you sent & I'm glad. Good Editor - you, I mean.
I'm still sad over Jimmie & I suppose I always shall be. But I made myself work all year

Children Throwing Snowballs
Detail of a Japanese painting 
Kanei era (1624-1643)
Edo period, Ukiyo-e school
Freer Gallery of Art
Smithsonian Institution
Washington, D.C. (73.12b)
on his collection for the academy & all?. Still have months to go. Honors for him continues. And I love doing this.
I've written only a few poems lately & feel they aren't very good. When I finish, I'll start a new book. But some of the meaning has gone out of my life. Maybe more time will help me work. I know I feel work is the best help, because we're most alive then. Healthier, I'm fine - and I'm passing thru stages.
Thank you for what you wrote to me in December mag. on your chapter story - You are a very generous person & I suspect helping others were up a lot of your writing time. But remember there are a great number of us out here & out there who want to read you.
Good wishes for the Holidays and a good full year of writing.
Fondly, 
Sanora
WXD 25-1747
Printed in Switzerland
Fort H. George Caspari, Inc.

P.S. You mentioned Loren Eiseley as a friend. How good that you two find men I knew reach other. I love every book of his. And I so admire his whole way of thinking & feeling. It is very sad that we'll have no more of his beautiful books. "Not Man Alone" paper published an excerpt from the Immense Journey cash into poetry. His prose was so often the finest poetry.

12/10/77
Sanora Babb
Jack, I got up my nerve to send 3 of the poems - if they are poems, I'm better at prose. Please don't embarrass yourself commenting. Write on your book. I'm just sending them as a little offering.
Some of the things I say may cause you to think I've "got religion". No, nothing orthodox ever. But I feel there's more than limited logic & that there's so much we don't know. The NY left editors used to accuse me of being mystical because of my "Nature

writing" so maybe that's true. I don't mind. I've had a lot of strange & interesting experiences of unclear. Maybe that's part of my Irish heritage.
August Derleth wrote to me late in life, after he read "Owl". (we used to be in the same little magazines) & reviewed it praisefully. He sent me a lot of his books, & said his psychic experiences caused his interest & belief in the supernatural - or perhaps it's only the preternatural. In any case it doesn't obliterate an interest in all else in life, & it rouses some more questions.
I read that we can soon listen to records of plants sounds - "talking & singing". Right now I'm play us a record of train sounds - old engines. More good wishes. S.
Drawn image of a tree, variety of birds, and a variety of creatures in winter.

Babb, Sanora
[1989]
2/ having you in it.
Good, good wishes!
Love,
Sanora
(Babb)

Happy Holidays
Dear Jack, I am so glad to have your greeting - I was just about to send mine to you at a wrong address.
I've thought of you so often & have been had about writing. I have heard about your courage and good spirits, you remarkable fellow! Keep getting better. The world itself is better for

Sanora Babb

Babb, Sanora [1983]
Greetings, Jack.
I'm late with my thanks for "The Disinherited" (I'm so glad to have it replaced) and for your warm, generous words to me. I am proud to be in the Anvil group - thank you, and thanks to you. You have helped a lot of writers.
You certainly have an admirer in Doug Wixson. I enjoyed our visit and his talk of you. I want to write you both soon.
My sister (Dorothy) is never well, so I am driving to Hemet?? to spend Christmas with her & cook her a good dinner. My dog, Higgins, a Chinese pug. Makes her laugh. Good medicine.

The only one I use.
I hopeyou have a 
healthful, fulfilling
year, Jack. I'm looking
forward to your autobiography.
Neglect us writers and give
us all your special
story. Enoy what I've read
My affectionate
greetings to you, Jack, 
and my admiration.
{Sanora}
(Both)

Seasons Greetings
Dear Jack, I've been hearing
about your courage and
improvement, and I hope you
will be better and better.
I never thought any of us
would grow old, did you?
And perhaps we didn't!

in pencil in top margin  Babb, Sanora  (1988)
2/
At the beginning of the year, I will
be (having been pressed into - not exactly
a familiar form to me - writing a
screen play about my husband's life.
A film company want to make such
a film. I plan to write only the first draft.
I still hope and expect to read
your autobiography. You've a special
life - especially marked with a lot
of real help to fellow writers.
Keep on keeping on. I admire
you, Jack, and have faith in your
ability to recover.
With my affection,
Sanora
(Babb)

Oct 30 - 63
Mr Jack Conroy
Dear Jack So sorry to heer of
you being Sick. Hope by this
time you are Feeling Better
and Home. I know a Little
about Being laid Up As I have
Emphysema along With 
Heart Trupel.  Well I saw Agnes
Monday She said you Went through
Operation O.K. Stanley said you
Were to tough to be laid up long.
Well Jack the Last time We
met We had a Short Talk of
Whitch I Enjoyed Verry mutch
O yes I Suppose you Left that
Book Disinherited at The
Tavern For me At Least

I Bought it any Way of Whitch
I have Through Twice Realy Enjoy
Reading it. Seemes that I could
Feele my own Wrest Hands
And Back Breaking in the 
Part About Those Paving
Brick Ha, Ha. As I also
Had to grab at a Straw
in Those Days. What Ever
Became of the Black 
Hand. Ha Ha.
Well Jack as I cant think of
any Thing of Empartant
Will Close
A Former Carman Appren
- test and R.R. Wabash Striker
Leslie E. Baker
410 Oak St
Huntsville Mo

Dear Jack:
Patty and me want to send our very
warm thnaks for your inscribed copy of The
Fast Sooner Hound that we've been enjoying
since Christmas. But how did you get our
address? Was it thru Christina? In any case,
it's immensly appreciated. I'd like to get
into the city to see the Folly of your ways, and
perhaps I'll be able to manage it come a warmer
season.
Best wishes
Orville Baker

Rainald V, Baker
Sept 30th 1964
Dear Jack and Mrs Conroy.
Delightful surprise today
to receive the "Disinherited" &
although I shall settle down with
great interest to reading it tonight
- the 30's was also a very painful
period for us too! - I wanted to
say a 'Very Kind thank you for 
remembering' to send it. Almost
unknown these days for people
to say they will do something &
then deliver!! I don't know whether

to blame such virtue on the English
Tea you embibed while over hear,
on you very nice people. - which
I strongly suspect.
Yours {aye}
Ray Baker

Dear Jack" - Fanny Cooke's address is 7068
Maryland, St Louis - sorry I didn't send it
sooner:... I told her you'd been brought up here
by friends from Moberty who would only stay
an hour. Write her, & write me so I know
what you wrote her... Blankfort was in town,
spending tomorrow at Vanguard; me chairman
says he's going to Moberly next... Went up to old
man {Michardt's} to fire him & give him enough of my mind to
keep him busy for the next nine minutes, but he pled mightely
and to some purpose, for when I left, "Sholem Asch's
new book, "The Mother" was under my arm and my soul,
my poor bartered soul for $4.16(?) was with him...
Even dogs have their day, and did you see Rohn & Phillips
defence in the N.M. with an editorial We Reply?....
Gregory's Anthology seems to be getting it too I see...
Haven't had chance yet to check printers with [Pretzhold.]
Have you written [Brals] people yet? - What's new? - Many lustrums!!
Jack [Balath]

"Dear Jack"
by Ed. Balchowsky
(With the minimum
of effort he had
tried to do what had
only been done by
the brave - , (who had
flung legs, hands,
head and heart into 
the conflict with unconcern)
As it has been pointed
to with pride (this
unconcern) by the
least of all included
in every other word
uttered (as though
it were in code) and

2
like one sentry
silhouetted on his
post of observation, -
from one hill to
the next the cry
speeds - , from one
brave unconcern to
the next, - we must
never let it die -
and in this today we
must face and are
prenatally looking away
from before noon - 
Before the dust of the 
early tradesman's boots
has become the sailing
surface of midday
idleness - Before caress
of evening cool rolls
down its sleeves and

3
takes a firm hold
on the top button of
the three sided cloak
of eternal trust, (in
unconcerned belief in
trust) - not for one 
moment doubting but 
facing quietly the
local masters of the
various art entrusted
to his care and
never failing in the
gentle undertaking of
relaxing the throttling
grip of poverty -
So, Jack! as I am 
working now and am 
going to have a
baby and fell

4
behind in the rent
because of a lot
of work on my
wifes' teeth the
landlady says she
must have an extra
$35 on the back 
rent. She has
given me until Thur. 
April 5; - would
you please let me 
have it Jack?
Reasonably yours
Balchowsky -
Ed Balchowsky
112 E. Superior

Happy Marseilles -
a pleasent Roshashana
and a prosperous Yom Kippur

April 28, 1961
Dear Jack:
That card - "you're
probably well by now" - is
just about right, I think
and hope!

  So, one of these days

the rested Bernard - not 
arrested, I hope, - will be
joining you at coffee and
gladly

  Will you tell all of 

the others - and also thank
all for their thoughts of
me?

  I am even getting feelings

of wanting to work. Does
that make me subversive,
to be exposed by the Birch
Society?

  My hand to you and all.

Sincerely,
Harry B-

[typed in top margin]  Harry Barnard
[letterhead]  Presbyerian St. Luke's Hospital  1753 West Congress Parkway  Chicago 12, Illinois   SEeley 5-4411
P.S.
As a more personal
note to you alone, Jack,
let me add:

  I have had much time

to think here, and some
of my thoughts have included
the realization that, for some
reason, I never got my
sea legs at the office - not
fully in a fellowship sense,
at least. I was the loser.

  My hope is that this will

be changed, and in particular
with you. For I am an
admirer of yours, Jack, as a 
person and as a writer. You 
have done much that has 
left all liberals still at
large in your debt. And,
besides, you are a good guy.
Being hospitalized gives me the

right, I think, to say
these things without
being "suspect". I mean
them.

  All this merely means

that I hope you and I
I - and your wife and
mine - can be more
than just fellow workers
in the salt mines, etc.
when I am back

  Maybe you will even

let me join you at
lunch!
HB
if Cuba and/or Laos
does not lead to us all
being blown to hell.

 Of course, that won't happen,

I guess, but I'm beginning
to wonder about JFK. I'm
[?eager?] to talk on this subject
with you.
H 
{1960's?}

June 5, 1983
Dear Jack Conroy,
Harry Barnard considered you
a top man in the roster of people
he cared about. And now I have to
write to tell you, if you hadn't
heard before this, that that remarkable,
wonderful guy so many people
loved, is gone. Last August 26,
he simply slipped away, within
seconds, clipping the N.Y. Times ...
The other evening, while going
through some of his papers, I
came upon your address, and
that is how it happens I'm
sending this note. All these
months have passed, and I still
can't absorb the fact that he's gone.
A terrible loss to friends, scholarship,
children, American literature.

and to me. And how sad it is that
he can't enjoy, any more, the Spring, 
the music of Beethoven, books, 
politics -- never have I knows
anyone so keenly interested in 
so many things...
I hope this finds you well and
active.
Sincerely,
Ruth Barnard
(Mrs. Harry)

A Friendly Christmas wish!

[inside of Christmas card, printed message]  May the cheery glow of friendship, Like a candle's golden light, Lend beauty to the Holidays And make your whole year bright!

Singing any Christmas

[Letterhead]  Bartlett   2875 Cowley Way - 1302  San Diego, CA  92110
July 1, 1980
Dear Jack,

  We're back from the Dorland Mt.

Colony today. A wonderfuly experience -
only 5 people on hundreds of acres!
Squirrels, rabbits, a deer, a fox, hawks,
owls... and dozens of wild flowers among 
the oaks, cacti, scrub bushes. Kerosene lamps
at night. So Paul and I enjoyed a month
of uninterrupted time for our writing: he, on

"Leonardo's Journal" and I, on a book of

memoirs.

  Among the letters waiting here was

yours with the good news about The Jack
Conroy Reader - we're happy and want to
order a copy! Bless Friday the 13th... wish
we could be on hand at Court's to improve
the sales count!

  Family news is always a mix of 

good and bad. Sorry Gladys is still ailing -
our regards and best wishes to her, please!

  I'm grateful for your interest

in my book, Address in Time, and
hope you'll like it. As you see, NEW
LETTERS doesn't pay any attention to
my work; even my letter gets returned!

So if you can manage a

review of my book there, I'd
be mighty pleased!

  My next book will be coming

from the Ohio University Press, a
collection of my new twelve-tone
poems, called "Memory Is No Stranger."
Since 13 is also my lucky number,
I hope the book does well.

  Lots of visitors coming our

way this summer, too. Our month
at Dorland will soon be a memory,
as life-as-usual, with the usual
interuptions, gets under way.

  Well, cheers anyway! Paul

will be writing to you later on.
Meanwhile, joint greetings and
abrazos.
Elizabeth

Villa Montalvo
Box 158
Saratoga
California
10 January 1961
Dear Jack:
I sent a copy of my "Owl" to Will and Motley,
at the Mexico City address you so kindly
gave. I hope that he takes an interest
in the movie possibilities. I
look forward to hearing from him ... of course
I wish I could be in Mexicao City & meet
him & talk with him: that is always
better, as you know.
Thanks, Jack, for your Christmas card. I liked
especially what you said: that my "Owl" 
will be around for a while. I hope so.
Did you hear my KFI broadcast a month
ago? I hope so.... I never got to meet
your friend Stoutmeyer. I'm sorry .... at
Huntington Hartford I finished a novel,
"Maker of Dreams" , a story of contemporary
Yucaton, a hypnotist, a Shageila setting,
on the palmera seacoast. The theme

with a J.J. Rousseau felling thta nature can
help us. I call the book a "history of 
happiness." It is with my agent, Curtis
Brown. As you realize, Curtis Brown
is a big outfit & I am a pebble there.
Could you suggest an agent who might
take a personal interest in my writing.
I have two novels & the completed
book-length MS of a collection of short
stories, "Mexican Footprints." About 18
of the 22 stories in this collection have
appeared in litarary publications. Please
feel free to suggest.
With every good wish for 1961...
Gratefully,
your ole Missourian ...

May 18, 1964
Dear Jack,
thank you for your good letter to me,
with a note for Don Wolfe. I am
seeing him this afternoon & will
give it to him.
I have been unable to get things
to Ken McCormick but I have been
treated cordially by Sonia Giop,
Lawerance Hill & Lillian Friedman.
I have seen a good many people
& I hope all this has been
worth while. Time will tell,
as you know.
People say fine things about
you & your work.
All my thanks...mil 
de gracias.. I'll be leaving
here on Thursday or Friday...
Paul

May 19, 1964
Dear Jack:
I left two novels with Mr. Hill,

"The novel is well done & a welcome

appealing elegaic strain & some

sections, are comparable to

MEMBER'S CORRESPONDENCE
I got Upton Sinclair to read the novel & he wrote:
"I found the book extremely interesting. I can't remember any account of tank fighting in such detail & so convincing."
John Dos Passos read it & writes:
"I read your book with a great deal of interest. The descriptions of tank fighting are great. You have a highly readable book that is very, very good."
My novel has the title "In the Beauty of the Lillies."

I am leaving tomorrow for California. My address there is the same: 6762-B SABADO TARDE ROAD, GOLETA, California.

Marques del Valle Hotel
Oaxaca 
January 1 — 1967
Dear Jack:
Best wishes for the new year, amigo!
As you see I am in Oaxaca, here for a few days rest. I had hoped to see The Ames. They are in Spain — Madrid, I believe. 
My Elizabeth & Steven gave me a plane ticket here for Christmas. A wonderful gift. Work has been strenuous at The University of California & I am happy to be here. 
The jacaranda trees are starting to bloom… so it is spring in Oaxaca. Spring is the best of all times to me. Spring in January is the proper date: all things beginning afresh. 
I have visited mitta & found the ruins disappointing. I had some fun, however, buying some old things: I came prepared & traded off three jackknives for various items: a seal, a clay head, a clay tiger. My son will value them. 
I hope Monte Alban is worth while. I plan to go there tomorrow… I will be visiting haciendas & sketching them. 
Surely wish you could be here. 
Hope Moberly life is satisfying to you, Jack… all my best for a happy 1968…
Paul

May 12, 1968
Hello, amigo: How are things with you? I hope all is well, that you are writing & publishing, & feel encouraged. Since I have not heard from you for months I come prodding you, gently...Recently I have finished my collection of 220 hacienda drawings, adding a few & completing expanded captions for each, for my 1-man show at The Hemisfair, June through September, sponsored by the University of Texas. I hope this can lead to book publication...In my writing, I have completed a novel, "Burning Glass," re my boyhood at Sault Ste Marie...long, long, long ago...My Elizabeth is recovering from spinal surgery, 2 months in 2 hospitals--quite an ordeal! Jan 19, 1971
Dear Jack Conroy,
The newspaper you asked us to send comes out about every 2 months. This is the latest copy.
We still have fine and pleasurable memories of our visit with you and Polly and I talk often about you and your family friendliness & kindness toward us when we came to see you. 
Since Sept I've (Inez) been working with Antioch students and a few teachers doing "workshops" in the public Schools in several cities in the area. The workshops are around issues that have potential of showing how this society works. Last quarter, sept. thru Dec. workshops were around the War in SE Asia--and Local Industry This quarter which has just begun the workshop are on the turn of the century. Examining this

II 

society during the Civil War period 1860 thru 1916--especially during the years of rapid industrial development. The Populist Movement, The Socialist Party development, the Womens movement & the Grangers (the muckrakers on one side)--the Yellow Press (on the other side of issues) The Labor movement--all developed during the influx of immigrants that period. I'm especially interested in the Socialization Process and dedication function during that period. Seeing what occured during that period will help us understand how development could have been different and what the factors and obstacles were that had to be overcome to make an alternative kind society possible.
Some books we're reading & studying are--Gabriel Kolko "Triumph of Conservatism" 1900-1916"Railroads & Regulations 1877-1916 Publishers WW Norton & Co Inc. New York--"The State in Capitalist Society" Ralph Milband Basic Books Inc. Publishers NY. Several Novels "The Jungle" Upton Sinclair publ New America" Library Inc Times Mirror 1301 Ave of Americas Ny NY 10019
"The Octopus" by Norris--"Looking

III
Backward"--by Edward Bellamy published by Houghton Mifflin Co. Boston. these 3 are novels--the 1st 2 on Railroad & Triumph of Conservatism are comprehensive historical accounts of that period. We're also studying "The State in Capitalist Society by Ralph Miliband publ. Basic Books Inc. New York. this is an analysis of Western system of power. "also" "The Decline of Socialism 1912-1925 in America" James Weinstein Vintage Giant press Division of Random House New York. this has an especially good section on the function of education of the period
All this material and much more we haven't listed we hope will give us a base of knowledge from which we can develope provocative-thought full-carefully planned workshop to do in the public schools with children of 2nd grade thru high school level. Thereby, Providing one kind of program which

IV
attempts to remove the obscurity of how this society works is a beginning step toward changing this society to an alternative one. Providing some sense of skills to critically analyze this society is another begining step. Before we can provide these skills to school children we must begin to have such a group of those skills ourselves. That's the reason for such need to study about how societyes are constructed, what developments produce what kind of conditions which produce what kind of relationships. Then looking at relationships in terms of interests. The role of the state--the role of industry--the function role of education--the role of the worker--the role of small business--& how these other groups fit together & how the differences within these groups fit together to make the turn of the century the most interesting period in the history of this country.
I hope you & your family are well. Please give them my regards. It was good hearing from you
Sincerely--love in struggle to change this society!!
Inez Baum

May 25, 1971
Dear Jack Conroy,
During the winter quarter here at Antioch college while studying a course on "Marx and the Aesthetics" we became very interested in proletarian literature of the period between 1929 and 1939. Our search lead us to "A World to Win"--
Almost from the beginning of the book we recognized it as an excellent example of good proletarian literature, which could only be written by an author who had experienced suffering with working and unemployed people in a very personal way. We would like to come and talk with you, because much of our work has to do with suffering people. 
One of us is a 16 year old student involved in politically organizing high schools. The other of us is a 52 year old Political Science college student with a background of 38 years in the labor force beginning as a leather factory worker at the age of 14. Our friendship developed when we were both selected for our political activity by radical women in this area of delegates to a conference with Indo Chinese women held at Toronto, Canada.

We look forward to hearing about our visit with you.
Love In Struggle
To Change our Society
For the Benefit of All
Inez Baum

Dear Jack + Gladys:
We are still sweltering in sunny St. L. Attempting to pay the bills, appease my salesmen + their customers, + please my boss + upper management. The older I become, I seem to realize, that there is no answer to the bitch goddess Success demands - A huge furnace with a red hot belly, once filled, emptied + ready for more - I have traveled quite a bit through the Midwest + South west, since I viewed your shining countaninces, + find - Capitalism, feudalism, Fascilism, + other "isms", living side by side, enjoying + using each other for their own selfish benifits. I am not disgusted, just niave, I guess - Nevertheless I am hoping someday to cease being an organizational misfit, + start a hotdog stand (with Beer) on the side of the road in the Ozarks + attempt to enjoy life. My 3 girls + son, are growing like weeds, and I am reminded that 20 years ago I was in the Navy + in the pacific -

Where does the time go? I remmember in 1950 our trip to St. L - with General MacConroy - How is Tom's unclear doing? Has the Girl remarried? Did you enjoy your trip abroad? Is progress being made, are the countries + people more affluent? We have been to Moberly + Macon twice this year, but with kids + relatives, I didn't get a chance to see your tribe or Tom - Iv'e been trying to see Will Wharton + Marian - But still no Luck. I managed to have a few words with Biggs + a promise for a beer unclear in the future. The Arch will be finished this Fall - So when you return from Europe + journey to "The Athens of the midwest". Perhaps we can have a party, with Will + the Rest?? I sure would like to see my old Literary Mentors of my lost youth. Im still writing short stories + throwing them away, my poems have no metre + my critics think I'm disorganized - Oh well, I still can enjoy being alive + somewhat of a Iconoclast - no Blacks + Whites, seems to be more grays in life than the others.
I reread the "disinherited" + find it better after each reading - I am hoping your Negroe Migration doesn't bog down - Yes, a great deal has happened since 1945 - Well J + C - all our love + let us hear from you soon 
Al Rosalie + the 4 Indians

I was in your theatre during the winter to see a film on China. There I ran across a book, "The Disinherited" by Jack Conroy. Betsy Weshoff, also at the theatre, that day, told me about Jack Conroy, history, etc, and that he lived in Moberly, MO. near Columbia, where I live. 
I am trying to get the book and read it. Also I would like to do an interview with the author for the On the Left program on KOPN radio. Possibly the author could come to Columbia and talk with some radical and socialist people in Columbia. 
I understand from Betsy that someone at the theatre knows the author personally or at least knows his address around Moberly. What I would like is his address so I may contact him about these proposals. If someone there could supply this information I would be deeply grateful.

1
Mr. Conroy,
I finally got your book from the MU library. I think I was wrong about McCarthy tricks in the case of your book. Probably just lousy shelving technique on part of the library staff. 
About your book, the Disinherited, I liked it very much. You seem to have the capacity of telling a story in genuine human terms. It reminds me somewhat of Steinbeck's techniques. But you do drive home the political point, something Steinbeck doesn't do with the same intensity. I guess thats why "The Distinguished" is called a proletarian novel.
I am just now having time to start reading literature after my graduation. Immediately after college I had to re-educate myself to politics. Now that I'm on a track thats logical and fitted to my own pre-dispositions I can read

around. And one of the literary genres is of course proletarian novels. I plan to do some reading of Paul Nizan whom I've read about in Monthly Review. 
My specific purpose in contacting you is for a possible interview (taped or live) about your book and about some of your experiences for KOPN radio here in Columbia. KOPN is called a "community radio", run by and for the community, free access, etc. Very much petty bourgeois counter culture oriented. But in spite of our differences with counter culture the people who produce the On the Left program for KOPN feel it is a good opportunity to pull some young people back into politics again and reach the other classes of people, besides students, who listen to KOPN. As socialists or communists seldom ever get the opportunity to utilize the air waves in this

3
country, we are using KOPN for both organizing and for training ourselves in utilizing the various possibilities for reaching the masses of people.
The people who produce "On the Left" can loosly be classified as socialist or socialist oriented. I class myself as communist, but not a very advanced one yet.
About the interview, if you consent: it could easily be taped in Moberly some evening or on the weekend. I work during the day but could drive up after work and anytime on the weekend would be fine. If your response is positive I can call you in Moberly and arrange the most conveinent time.
And if you are in Columbia any time please feel free to call me (442-8922). I am certain we could have some interesting conversations.
Rubert Baumgartner

May 4. 1954
Mr. JackConroy
Chicago, Illinois
Dear Mr. Conroy,
It was kind of you to write the letter in which you mentioned the Nemoscope article. I was asked to write a series of articles about north-east Missouri writers. I mentioned Nelson of La Plata, Mrs. McLorn (Olive Gilbreath) La Plata, Mrs. Gasparotti, Moberly; Mary Margaret McBride of Paris; Mr. Blanton of Paris; Miss Minnie Brashear of Kirksville; Rupert Hughes, of Lancaster; Glen Frank of Greentop etc. 
Mr. Conroy, your writing of children's books interest me very much. I teach courses in children's literature here at K.S.T.C., taught one summer in Missouri University and taught courses in that subject two different summers in California State College at San Jose. 
I have two manuscripts which you might be interested in. If you would care to be a co-author of either, or both, and manage the publication with out any cost to me I shall be glad to send them to you for consideration. One is written with a rural life slant, Cappy, the Canary, the story of a pet pig, a canary, and a little old lady on a farm - grade 1-2-3 level - picture book style. The other, Run-away Rabbit, also has a rural slant. 
These are but two I have read to

letterhead  NORTHEAST MISSOURI    STATE TEACHERS COLLEGE    KIRKSVILLE, MISSOURI
children in many primary rooms. I told them over our local radio as I was "Story-Telling Lady" on the Children's Hour for several years and wrote my stories for the radio programs which were broadcast over a sixty mile area.
Dr. Germane of Missouri University and Dr. Rodney of this college both urge me to get them published, but I know very little about approaching publishers. 
I shall be glad to hear from you regarding the stories.
Sincerely,
Berenice B. Beggs.

letterhead  NORTHEAST MISSOURI    STATE TEACHERS COLLEGE    KIRKSVILLE, MISSOURI
May 12, 1954
Dear Mr. Conroy,
I was so happy to receive a copy of Midland Humor and particularly pleased to have the writing in front. I presume one feels a tie with homefolks that makes writing to them easy and natural, and "homefolks" means some one from the old home town.
I was born and reared in Moberly, went to school at South Park, graduated from the Moberly High School, taught in Central School, then later in the High School.  My sister, Camille Beggs, taught grade one in West Park about 1920. My sister, Beulah, was deputy Probate Judge of Randolph County with the office in Moberly. (1922-1928)
I heard of your first through The Anvil which you often sent me. I knew you went to West Park, and later the high school, but really never met you.
We have a copy of Sam Patch in our

letterhead  NORTHEAST MISSOURI    STATE TEACHERS COLLEGE    KIRKSVILLE, MISSOURI
Childrens Library on the College campus, and I saw that copies were ordered for the two Demonstration Schools because I knew the children would enjoy reading it. I am pleased beyond measure to have a copy sent to me by you as my very own. 
I am wondering if A.A. Wyn Publisher, publishes juvenile books.
May I thank you again.
Sincerely,
Berenice B Beggs

returned after 30 years of teaching Children's

in State Teachers College at Kirksville.

of The Anvil and Sam Patch as well as

has reason to be proud of your many

   The college published my poetry in a booklet and distributed copies to teachers in the sixteen county district.

June  19, 1969
Mr. Jack Conroy
Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri
Dear Mr. Conroy:

   I believe I appreciate your great contribution in literature more than anyone in Moberly, the place of your birth.  How well I recall reading from your little magazine, The Anvil when it was first published.  I wish I had saved my copies.  I treasure greatly the autography copy of Midland Humor and Sam Patch also, which you so kindly sent me.
  While I was teaching a course in Children's Literature at California State College at San Jose, and also teaching at North-east Missouri State College, both I placed on required reading lists.
  I plan to give a program to a Moberly Club in the fall, reading and discussing your books; if you don't object.
  I believe in the old saying, "A prophet is without honor in his own country."

I feel that is true even from my own experience for I seldom speak of my past experiences in this town of my birth.  I too was brought up in a modest home but fortunately my father was a former  De Pauw University student and my mother a well-read person who cared little about social status etc and I may have had little luxuries in a material way but was surrounded by books which enriched my whole life.

  My writing contribution has been mainly to educational magazines in the teaching profession, (50 articles) in 7 national and state magazines.  I still long to break into print with the stories I wrote when I conducted a children's story hour on radio station KIRX.
   I have been tempted to call on  you but know how involved you are.  I listened to your conversation on Leah Lowe's program and your comments on the Irish.  My fathers family came from a Scotch settlement in Ireland, (County Antrim).
  I was disappointed to discover that only two of your books were in the city library.  I wanted to reread The Disinherited and was told the only copy was out

and I could be placed on the waiting list.  I was pleased to know it is now considered a classic.  You were ahead of the times although criticized for being a ? writer at the time.

   I was gone from Moberly for thirty years living in a stimulating environment with opportunities to travel and to speak to audiences interested in wide fields.  I had the pleasure of hearing Hamlin Garland, Pearl Buck, Vachel Lindsay, & Carl Sandburg  Lorado Taft, Stephen Leacock, Charles A Beard  Stricken Gilliland, Dorothy Thompson  John G. Neihardt, Glen Frank and a number of others while on the faculty.
  I attended a story writers' workshop in Evanston conducted by Rowena Bennett about the time you were there.
  Please know how proud I am of your advancement from the time you were a Moberly school boy.
  Pardon, if this all seems boresome.

Sincerely,
Berenice A. Beggs

November 10, 1971
Dear Jack,

   I have just finished reading "Days Of the Anvil" in the issue of American Book Collector which you sent to me.  I found the article very comforting, particularly in view of my current turmoil with Open Places.   There are many differences between your experiences with Anvil and my Open Places.  The most obvious difference is that you had a definite social, if not political, motivation in publishing Anvil.  I never had any real purpose in mind in starting O.P. other than to publish poems that I liked and to keep myself busy and involved with some segments of the literary mode.  I have never been a writer myself, but have always been very much in love with writers and writing - rather adolescent I know.   So between having babies - I have three daughters - the magazine seemed a more interesting outlet for me than anything else I might possibly undertake.  Besides, it is what I wanted to do without any more real reasoning about it than that.  I have no particular intellectual ideas about what should or should not be published.   So Open Places is a rather mixed bag of tastes and styles.  I began the magazine in theFall of 66' when my husband I were living in New York City.  He was teaching English at Brooklyn College.  In 68',

2.
at the time our third child was due, we moved here to Columbia and my husband began teaching at the University here.   I found it much easier to sustain the magazine in N.Y. where so many poets were interested in it and money was easier to raise.  Columbia  was a real let down.  I have never really been able to establish my own identity or believability here.   I have had to work much harder to stimulate submissions and subscriptions.  Whereas in N.Y. things were much easier.  I was always meeting poets and editors and the whole whirl was far more encouraging.

   I don't know if you know a Max Baird who used to live here in Columbia.  Max worked for the U of Mo. Press for awhile.   Well I was about to give up on O.P. altogether for financial reasons, having applied for and been turned down on many a grant application.   Max put up the money for two issues and bought all of my stationary and helped me to find subscribers, etc.  Then Max had some severe personal problems and had to leave Columbia.  I was able to raise quite a lot of money by doing some free lance editing which suddenly fell my way, and I put out a double issue and another single issue.
   This summer I was feeling very frustrated with the financial problems again.  I had applied for and been refused a grant

3.
for the fourth time.  A friend suggested I try Stephens College.  He felt they just might go for the idea of subsidizing a little magazine.  The creative writing staff there approved of the idea and so did the Dean.   I was able to get that last issue, No. 10, out immediately with no problem.  Then came No. 11!  It was agreed that members of the staff would act as advisory editors.  So that when I & my students - all 3 of them - had selected the poems I met with my advisory board.  I have never experienced anything like it.  They did not like any of the poems I selected.  At least not all three of them could agree on any one poem.   They were agressive [sic], vindictive and absolutely absurd in their criticism of what I was doing.   One member voiced the opinion that if a poem was not up to the standard of what he called, in fact mimed from  T.S. Eliiot, "High" art, then it should not be published.  I could obviously rant on for hours about what went on in that meeting.  The crux of it is that I can go ahead with this issue but for the next issue I must not accept any poems without their prior approval.  I am just to weed out the "bad" stuff

and send on to them the rest for their comment.  In other words, I am to become a secretary for my own magazine.   I don't have to tell you how disturbed I am about all of this.  I have actually lost sleep over it.   The irony of it is that if it were not for Max Baird I would have let the magazine die after four issues back in 1968.  And if Stephens had not have decided to subsidize it this fall I am quite certain that the magazine would have just not come out again.  Now, faced with the afrontery [sic] of Stephens College and their sophmoric,[sic]  intellectual bigotry -  I am all angry and upset about the threat to my position as Editor, founder and Princess to Open Places.

  I can't see how I can continue with Stephens.  I am just going to have to withdraw O.P. from their clutches.  Perhaps I am being overly dramatic.  I tend to respond with my whole being to everything and this has been very upsetting for me.  I had thought that I hd finally worked up to something.   That I had won a real coup with Stephens.  They were never interested in me.  They were just concerned to take over my magazine.

Well enough.  I don't want to bore you.  I bothered to tell you all of this not to gain your sympathy - but your empathy.  Needless to say - I am very impressed with the history of The Anvil & the New Anvil.  And the writers of the the [sic] Anvils that is very interesting.  You have accomplished a good deal.

   I am going to check the library for the Disinherited.   I would like to read it and I'm certain that it must be there.   
   So, finally,  I am pleased to have acquired a friendship with you.  Open Places was worth that.   Do you ever get into Columbia?  Could you & your wife come and have dinner with us sometime?  My husband Bob is very interested to meet you.  He is from Chicago and he had a prof. at IIT who used to talk about your book quite often.
   I enjoyed your "Home to Moberly" very much also.  It is sad that the MLA quarterly has to be the hottest literary quarterly going these days.   I had meant to discuss in the letter the differences between magazines of the 30's like yours and mg. of present like mine.  It is a sad commentary that there is so little literary movement and

farce in the independent magazines today.  So many are so dull.   It is also ironic that so many poets whom I have published are poets from the 30's.
I must send you a complete set of Open Places as a gift.  I will do that this week.   I am also returning your little pamphlets.  Very entertaining and more lively reading than most things around.  do try and come and see us.  Let's set a date.
All the best,
Eleanor
P.S. Tharpe wrote again to say the article on O.P. forthcoming eventually.

Dear Jack - 
I have not been able to get off a real letter to you - but I would like to wish you and your wife a very Merry Xmas and Prosperous New Year. I have read the "Disinherited" - and loved it. I found it very moving and beautifully written. I have been having fun reading other novels of that period also and some of the Criticism of the period and find the

latter very amusing.

  Open Places will be printed around the first week in Jan.   Things are going quite well at Stephens - which is to say that I have not seen anyone over there for several days.  We have our big policy planning meeting in Jan for O.P.   I am calmed down about the whole thing now.  I hope that I can be diplomatic and tactful - but I guess that is dreaming.  Say -enjoy the holidays -  Eleanor

Aug 16th
Dear Jack:

   Its been 12 days since I had Muriel's letter with the news of your great loss.  Since then I've been thinking about you and wanting to say something of comfort, yet here I've been sitting with heavy hand, and pen almost imobile [sic], as I know no words with which to soothe or comfort you.
   Sad enough this unhappy world without such unnecessary waste and loss.  I am so sorry.
   I never met your boy Tom but heard from others that he was a fine and sensitive person.
   I look upon Harry and often ponder over the complete selflessness of the man and How he lives only for his children.   Are all parents like that?  If so what a great loss of oneself

is gone when a child goes!

  As for me - I sometimes feel I've lived too much alone to enjoy anything other than the mental life of anticipation of happenings except for those rare occasions when I whip up enough enthusiasm to do things creative with my hands.  Perhaps at such times the frustrations of no realization from dreaming are gone momentarily and replaced by activity.
   There is so much to do around here yet while writing this letter I'm sharing the doing with gazing through the open slats of the venetian blinds which disclose a vision of rooftops reminiscent of Paris and nostalgia for a past more carefree day - Please consider

a former proposal I made and visit us.

   San Francisco has much which is diverting, and you have a number of admirers here already.

Sincerely
Rose Bergman
